text:
Hey folks, I'm currently thinking a lot about all the different people that are involved & work with content management systems. So here's my question:

*Which role (job title) is the main champion & decision maker when it comes to your content management systems (CMS) in your company?*

elements.text: Hey folks, I'm currently thinking a lot about all the different people that are involved & work with content management systems. So here's my question:
Which role (job title) is the main champion & decision maker when it comes to your content management systems (CMS) in your company?

text: Hi Tom in my organization (a nonprofit) that would be me (digital communications manager) and my boss (chief comms officer). My boss holds final decision making power as far as budget and investing in new tools or enhancing our CMS but my feedback has major sway since I use it day to day and am in charge of website management.

elements.text: Hi Tom in my organization (a nonprofit) that would be me (digital communications manager) and my boss (chief comms officer). My boss holds final decision making power as far as budget and investing in new tools or enhancing our CMS but my feedback has major sway since I use it day to day and am in charge of website management.

text: <@U01CW2WDEEP> Thanks for this, Yasemin!

elements.text: Thanks for this, Yasemin!

text: Hey y’all! Quick question about content strategy: I’ve been building a blog for Homerun very gradually over the past year and one of my main goals so far has been simply to figure out what topics bring us traffic. My question is: at how many visitors do you think it becomes possible to draw useful conclusions about what topics are working. Our numbers are quite low (1,600 monthly visitors) and I’m just wondering if it makes sense to say ‘we should double down on this type of content’ based on the low numbers. Do I need to wait for our numbers to increase significantly before determining which topics lead to compounding traffic?

elements.text: Hey y’all! Quick question about content strategy: I’ve been building a blog for Homerun very gradually over the past year and one of my main goals so far has been simply to figure out what topics bring us traffic. My question is: at how many visitors do you think it becomes possible to draw useful conclusions about what topics are working. Our numbers are quite low (1,600 monthly visitors) and I’m just wondering if it makes sense to say ‘we should double down on this type of content’ based on the low numbers. Do I need to wait for our numbers to increase significantly before determining which topics lead to compounding traffic?

text: I’d say that’s pretty early for a “let’s double down on X”. I’d run some tests, create different content pieces based on your audience. Promote them, see how they perform. Look beyond just traffic, look at trials created, installs, newsletter subs, etc. KPIs that tie into potential revenue. As soon as you see that some of the piece are working, create some adjacent ones and see if they do equally well and take it from there. If they too perform well you’ve got a pretty good data set to base your decision on (and get backing for resources etc.)

elements.text: I’d say that’s pretty early for a “let’s double down on X”. I’d run some tests, create different content pieces based on your audience. Promote them, see how they perform. Look beyond just traffic, look at trials created, installs, newsletter subs, etc. KPIs that tie into potential revenue. As soon as you see that some of the piece are working, create some adjacent ones and see if they do equally well and take it from there. If they too perform well you’ve got a pretty good data set to base your decision on (and get backing for resources etc.)

text: I agree with <@U014PRHQUQ2> on looking beyond traffic. Traffic alone can be very deceiving.

elements.text: I agree with
on looking beyond traffic. Traffic alone can be very deceiving.

text: <@U01MVN90X9U> thanks for the insights! I'm really interested to see which department is owning "CMS" & website tech budgets.

elements.text: thanks for the insights! I'm really interested to see which department is owning "CMS" & website tech budgets.

text: In our case the CMS for the org’s external facing website is owned by Communications. The Intranet is owned by IT. Project specific websites are owned by individual projects. The maintenance responsibilities and budgets are determined accordingly

elements.text: In our case the CMS for the org’s external facing website is owned by Communications. The Intranet is owned by IT. Project specific websites are owned by individual projects. The maintenance responsibilities and budgets are determined accordingly

text: Thanks for the advice! Indeed it’s not all about traffic (I’m looking at newsletter subs and trials as well) but traffic seems like the thing I can start drawing conclusions about the soonest. But what you’re saying is that it’s too early for even that right? What kind of numbers (like order of magnitude) would you say you’re able to tell whether content is working?

text:
*Hiring / Interviewing Candidates*
We are hiring content strategists right now, and I'd like to give them some sort of writing test + some sort of editing test to measure their chops on that front. (My experience has been that writing samples are helpful but not raw, so it's good to see something raw to understand what it looked like before it got edited and published.)

I do not want to make them spend a ton of time on this or create a ton of work for me/the hiring team.

So my question:
• What have you seen work well for a short writing / editing assignment in the interview process?
• What recommendations would you have around how to think about putting this together & executing it?
Open to any/all thoughts! TIA!

elements.text: Hiring / Interviewing Candidates

We are hiring content strategists right now, and I'd like to give them some sort of writing test + some sort of editing test to measure their chops on that front. (My experience has been that writing samples are helpful but not raw, so it's good to see something raw to understand what it looked like before it got edited and published.)

I do not want to make them spend a ton of time on this or create a ton of work for me/the hiring team.

So my question:
What have you seen work well for a short writing / editing assignment in the interview process?
What recommendations would you have around how to think about putting this together & executing it?
Open to any/all thoughts! TIA!

text:
Well, are you hiring a _strategist_ or a _writer_, or both?

They can be two very different roles, and the catchall of "content strategist" can leave some critical details out. (Content = video, visuals, copy, longform, ads, etc crossed by strategy, production, distribution, analysis—taken broadly, there can be two dozen roles that could be called "content strategist..." but I digress).

If you're really after strategy, then I'd agree that a writing sample is a poor measure of strategic thinking. The sample is an isolated measure of tactical execution.

A better exercise for a strategist IMO would be to put together a brief, and/or look at an existing brief and analyze it (I'd want to see if they ask strategic questions, identify what's missing from the brief, see if they're looking at this thing from a high-level vs tactical output). <@U01N4EQQTL6>

elements.text: Well, are you hiring a
strategist
or a
writer

, or both?

They can be two very different roles, and the catchall of "content strategist" can leave some critical details out. (Content = video, visuals, copy, longform, ads, etc crossed by strategy, production, distribution, analysis—taken broadly, there can be two dozen roles that could be called "content strategist..." but I digress).

If you're really after strategy, then I'd agree that a writing sample is a poor measure of strategic thinking. The sample is an isolated measure of tactical execution.

A better exercise for a strategist IMO would be to put together a brief, and/or look at an existing brief and analyze it (I'd want to see if they ask strategic questions, identify what's missing from the brief, see if they're looking at this thing from a high-level vs tactical output).

text:
What Jordy said ^^

+ If you are looking for a writer, ask them to write something (and pay them).

+ If you are looking for an editor, ask them to edit something (and pay them).

text: Yes, fair question! We're looking for someone who can do both strategy and execution, a bit more weighted on execution. I feel like I can ask good questions and get a sense for their strategy chops in an interview, though your point is a good one. Writing and editing is harder to assess in an interview...

elements.text: Yes, fair question! We're looking for someone who can do both strategy and execution, a bit more weighted on execution. I feel like I can ask good questions and get a sense for their strategy chops in an interview, though your point is a good one. Writing and editing is harder to assess in an interview...

text: Yes, I have no problem paying them to do the work. My question is what type of assignment you've seen work well. It's tough to gauge someone's ability to learn an industry/niche and write well about it in one sample... How do I get an approximation of that?

elements.text: Yes, I have no problem paying them to do the work. My question is what type of assignment you've seen work well. It's tough to gauge someone's ability to learn an industry/niche and write well about it in one sample... How do I get an approximation of that?

text:
I'd be wary of "both but mostly tactical"

Too often those roles end up really being 99% execution and a nod towards strategy. Better to just hire someone for execution and let them know there's room to grow into higher order stuff. Issue being if you attract candidates that expect to do 25-75% and it ends up being basically all execution, it may disappoint.

elements.text:

text: Problem being that "strategy" rarely has an agreed upon definition between orgs and people :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Problem being that "strategy" rarely has an agreed upon definition between orgs and people

text:
If it's writing, ask for samples, yes? Editing is a different ball game where could get them to do a piece then the rest is trusting their portfolio is actually theirs. For the right company, I'd happily write a piece following a brief, and edit a piece, with your guidelines.

And again in agreement with Jordy, my role as a Content Strategist is rarely about execution. I spend most of my time researching, writing briefs, optimising, planning promotion, and managing writers. But, there's a lot of full -time roles that are the complete opposite.

elements.text:

text:
Again, totally fair points, thank you for sharing those perspectives. We're a small content agency, growing quickly. I'm interviewing folks with an eye toward hiring people based on what they can bring to the table.

If someone brings more writing and editing chops to the table, we can craft a role around that; ditto strategy. I'm being totally honest during interviews about the mix of strategy and execution, and again we're growing fast so there is room for people to do more and less of what they do and don't want to do.

I do appreciate the feedback on the role title, but I'm asking more specifically about what types of writing and editing assignments you have seen work well in the hiring process.

elements.text:

I do appreciate the feedback on the role title, but I'm asking more specifically about what types of writing and editing assignments you have seen work well in the hiring process.

text:
Confused as to types of assignments you mean?
For me, I'd want something like:

• Write us a 1,000 word blog post on this topic with these keywords etc
• Edit this piece from a junior copywriter so it's best optimised for SEO, matches our TOV document, and is the best version it can be.

text: I guess what I'm trying to get at is, what types of assignments have you found to be illuminating re: someone's ability to think critically about a space and write well for a specific audience? (Again, I'm happy to pay and have a bias for shorter content in a situation like this)

elements.text: I guess what I'm trying to get at is, what types of assignments have you found to be illuminating re: someone's ability to think critically about a space and write well for a specific audience? (Again, I'm happy to pay and have a bias for shorter content in a situation like this)

text: I just hired and tried a new assignment type, which was asking them to write a short post about their biggest content marketing “win”. I kept it pretty open-ended, encouraged them to get creative and show their personality. It didn’t require any research or knowledge of our space or company. But it was VERY telling.

I kept it pretty open-ended, encouraged them to get creative and show their personality. It didn’t require any research or knowledge of our space or company. But it was VERY telling.

text:
When I was in-house, it was always my role - as whatever my title was as the senior marketer in the business (it wasn't ever IT or some other department).

As a consultant, most of the smaller businesses that I work with have an idea of what they want to use, but are open to options from me/developers

text:
:wave::skin-tone-2: *This is for the content marketers within enterprises and high-growth B2B startups.*

I’m starting a blog dedicated specifically to you.

Most content marketing…content… is geared toward beginner/intermediate marketers. I’ll be covering everything from navigating company politics and getting buy-in, to running teams and creating better content.

_Curious though -_What kinds of things would _you_ want to see covered in a blog like this?

text:
>  What kind of numbers (like order of magnitude) would you say you’re able to tell whether content is working? 
This is hard to put a number on, as for some companies those 1600 visitors you have right now would keep the phone ringing in the sales department, whereas with other companies it would be crickets. It really depends on the business.

I’d say you know whether content is working when you try a couple of pieces, and for each one you list the expected outcome and you see if the actual outcome matches (or is pretty close). Obviously, that outcome should be in line with what the business needs, or at the very least work towards it.

text:
I would love to see something like this, but in my experience the moment you move past the basics you go into the realm of “super specific”.

Advice at that level isn’t something you can speak to generically anymore. It’s specific problems, and not everyone is going to have that specific problem and so your advice is less relatable to your other readers.

It’s the “Dear Abby” level of thought leadership

text:
If you've run a content/media consumption survey (like through SurveyMonkey or Typeform) to your audience before, what were some of the most helpful questions you asked? Or, care to share the survey itself :wink:?

Context: My company has a sizable list of newsletter subscribers (90k+), a buzzing content operation, and an engaged audience. I'm hoping to run an informal research survey to help determine how to level up our content strategy.
